original_title: Sri Lanka to adjust wages and pensions to inflation: President
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT- Sri Lanka plans to raise state wages and pensions to account for inflation, President Ranil Wickremesinghe said as the country’s 12-month inflation was pushed to 70 percent in 2022 by the central bank.
“We expect to adjust salaries and wage to inflation,” President Ranil Wickremesinghe told parliament during a statement on an International Monetary Fund agreement.
“But this adjustment will be done within the limits of a primary deficit.”
Sri Lanka has keep annual targets on the primary deficit under the IMF program.
Related Sri Lanka meets 4.0-pct primary deficit target for 2022
Sri Lanka has already over-performed on the primary deficit of 954 billion rupees in 2022 by around 59 billion rupees.
According to the IMF program documents will develop ways contain the public salary bill while avoiding salary cut.

There will be “limited public sector salary and public pension payment increases to partially account for inflation during the program” which will be within its primary balance targets. (Colombo/Mar22/2023 – Updated. Headline changed to adjust instead of linked to clearly say it is not fully linked to inflation)
